Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Chip-scale laser ranging module for precision autonomous navigation and vehicular safety
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of precision laser sensing for vehicular navigation and safety. Recently, there has been a substantial commercial effort to build modular light detection and ranging (LiDAR) units to achieve the perception stack of autonomous and robotic-drone platforms. However, most state-of-the-art LiDAR sensors are based on mechanically rotating laser arrays or bulk solid-state lasers that are large, heavy, consume high-power and are difficult to scale. Recent results have demonstrated a chip-scale LiDAR architecture based on on-chip lasers and optoelectronics, enabling a solid-state approach with high performance. In this I-Corps program, the goal is to identify potential customers and market of highest need through the customer discovery process, and to develop a detailed and robust business model.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of precision laser sensing for vehicular navigation and safety and supported by preliminary chip demonstrations in the laboratory. Using this technology, the 3D vehicular surroundings may be mapped via laser time-of-flight reflection. Together with modeling and design parameter analysis, performance of the LiDAR chip has been examined using advances in the photonic design, coupled with advances in the laser precision measurements and thresholds, and detector signal-to-noise ratio. The photonic implementation is scalable through the foundry processing compared to prior studies on bulk rotating laser arrays or bulky solid-state lasers. This chip-scale laser sensing technology may enable the readiness level of autonomous vehicle sensors.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light detection and ranging (LiDAR) is a foundational sensing element for vehicular navigation and safety, wherein the 3D vehicular surroundings are mapped via laser time-of-flight reflection. Recently there has been substantial commercial effort to build modular LiDAR units to achieve the perception stack of autonomous and robotic platforms. However, most state-of-the-art LiDAR sensors are based on mechanically rotating laser arrays or bulk solid-state lasers that are large, heavy, consume high-power and difficult to scale. Recently our UCLA team has a chip-scale LiDAR architecture, based on chip-scale lasers and with state-of-the-art positional resolution and sampling rates. This core technology is based on NSF-supported efforts over the past 5 years.

This project enables the development of good product-market fit, the extensive on-the-ground customer discovery, and discover new pathways for our technology commercialization and transition. We learnt from the I-Corps instructors and within the Business Canvas Model framework. We learnt the methodologies of customer discovery, seeking the pain points to improve our technology commercialization. These methodologies also aided our startup translation of our research effort.

116 customer interviews were performed to guide the project I-Corps development. We examined entirely new market segments that we did not anticipate when entering into this program. Working with the entrepreneurial lead and I-Corps team mentor, we planned new pathways, discovered potential new customers, and applied the I-Corps framework to improve our product-market fit. This effort significantly guided our current PFI-TT effort, to translate into a SBIR effort for this technology commercialization. 

This project has support the training of a graduate student and the PI. It has embedded more technology knowledge to the I-Corps mentor.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/05/2021
Modified by: Chee Wei Wong

Recently our UCLA team has a chip-scale LiDAR architecture, based on chip-scale lasers and with state-of-the-art positional resolution and sampling rates. This core technology is based on NSF-supported efforts over the past 5 years. This project enables the development of good product-market fit, the extensive on-the-ground customer discovery, and discover new pathways for our technology commercialization and transition. We learnt from the I-Corps instructors and within the Business Canvas Model framework.
